words: Oh, they expect a lot of things.

speaker: RORY
words: I don't know. It was just one big, long, scary, tweedy, bad eight hours.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Add some hair spray, and you've got my day.

speaker: RORY
words: One of the girls already hates me, the guys are weird.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, they kept calling me Mary.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're kidding me. Wow, I can't believe they still say that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mary, like Virgin Mary. It means they think you look like a goody-goody.

speaker: RORY
words: Well, what would they have called me if they thought I looked like a slut?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, they might have added a Magdalene to it.

speaker: RORY
words: Wow, biblical insults. This is an advanced school.
[It's nighttime. Lorelai, Rory, and Lane are walking down the sidewalk eating slices of pizza.]

speaker: LANE
words: It was so weird not having you in school today. I mean, I finally noticed some of the other kids, and let me just say, they are a sad lot.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, well, add a couple of plaid skirts, and you've got the Chilton freaks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey guys, I have an idea. What about, on Tuesdays and Thursdays, you know, when I go into Hartford for my business class, what if Lane comes along, and you guys can shop and study and join a cult and shave your heads.

speaker: LORELAI
words: All except the shaving your heads part.

speaker: LANE
words: Oh, no. What time is it?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Again? Lane, your mother is gonna kill me if I keep sending you home fed and happy.

speaker: LANE
words: I'm sorry, but she found a web site that sells Tofu in bulk.

speaker: LANE
words: Yesterday, she went out and bought a bigger fridge.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Boy, now, your life is scary.

speaker: LANE
words: [to Rory] Can I have your crust?

speaker: RORY
words: [hands her the pizza crust] It's the least I can do.
[Lane leaves. Lorelai and Rory continue walking down the sidewalk]

speaker: RORY
words: I wish I could figure out a way to get Paris off my back.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, angry chicks are the worst. When I was in high school I had a Paris.

speaker: RORY
words: How'd you get rid of her?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I got pregnant and dropped out.

speaker: RORY
words: What if I just learn to French braid her hair?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Even better. Sweetie, you can't let those kids get you down.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Do you want me to talk to anybody? A parent, a teacher, a big guy named Moose?

speaker: RORY
words: I'll just figure it out for myself.

speaker: RORY
words: I was just thinking about the way Paris' face looked when I beat her to that Martin Luther question.
[they stop in front of Luke's Diner and see Luke inside]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, what do you think of Luke?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I mean, do you think he's cute?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I said nothing about dating Luke.

speaker: RORY
words: If you date him, you'll break up, and we'll never be able to eat there again.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I repeat, I said nothing about dating Luke.

speaker: RORY
words: Date Al from Pancake World, his food stinks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I cannot believe what I'm hearing. Al's food does not stink, Al stinks.
[Luke comes out of the diner and watches them walk away, then puts up the "Closed" sign and goes back inside.]
(The scene opens at the Gilmores' weekly dinner.)

speaker: EMILY
words: Mira does make a perfect cassoulet.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I thought the cook was Heidi.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, no, we let Heidi go months ago. She had a problem closing things -- the door, the refrigerator --

speaker: EMILY
words: Then it was Trina, then Sophia.

speaker: EMILY
words: She was the one who sang.

speaker: EMILY
words: And after Sophia we had Anton.

speaker: RICHARD
words: That's right. Anton was the one that I liked.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm sorry, Dad, how do you mix up Anton and Sophia?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well, one is a man and one is a woman.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That one is a man and one is a woman.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I have a lot to do in a day, Lorelai, I don't have time to keep up with a multitude of people that your mother employs.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But one is a man and one is a woman.

speaker: LORELAI
words: The dinner was so wonderful, Mira.

speaker: RORY
words: Hey, Grandma, these plates are really pretty.

speaker: EMILY
words: Thank you, Rory. They were your great-grandmother's.

speaker: RORY
words: I thought Mom was the first.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, but in so many other things I was a regular trailblazer. Just finishing your thought, Mom.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Lorelai the first was my mother. She was an extremely accomplished equestrian, a distinguished patron of the arts, and she was also world-famous for her masquerade balls. She was quite a woman, my mother.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes she was. Mira, come cut the cake please.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yes, and why don't you bring Sarah out here with you?

speaker: EMILY
words: So, Lorelai, how are things at that charming little inn of yours?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mm -- they're still charming and little. We're just crossing our fingers it doesn't assert itself and become rude and large.

speaker: RORY
words: Mom's having a huge wedding there this week.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, actually there's people coming from all over the country.

speaker: EMILY
words: I'm sorry, was there more to the story?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Uh, Rory has to pick a team sport to play.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Physical fitness is as important as intellectual fitness. So says Plato and so say I.

speaker: EMILY
words: What sport are you going to pick?

speaker: RORY
words: I'm not sure. I'm not really the athletic type.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I told her she should go out for the debating team.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It is the way the Gilmores play.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well your grandfather is a golf player.

speaker: EMILY
words: He plays every week at the club. He could teach you to play like a pro.

speaker: EMILY
words: Why, he could take you there on Sunday. It's perfect.

speaker: RICHARD
words: It's not something you can teach in an afternoon.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That's OK. Rory can pick something else.

speaker: EMILY
words: Why should she pick something else? She needs to learn a sport and Richard can teach her a sport. (to Rory) You can use your mother's old golf clubs. They're upstairs gathering dust along with the rest of her potential.

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, Mom, can I maybe talk to you for a minute?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know but I'd like to talk to you fast before the sugar sets in and makes me crazy.
(Lorelai and Emily get up from the table and go into another room to talk.)

speaker: EMILY
words: What is so important it can't wait for cake?

speaker: EMILY
words: This is as far as I can go unless you'd like me to bore my way through the wall.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Force Rory and Dad to go golfing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well you're manipulating the situation in a way that gives no one a way out. That's force. Look it up.

speaker: EMILY
words: I'm just trying to help your daughter get an education.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. She'll find another sport.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Because she doesn't want to go and Dad doesn't want to take her.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, your father doesn't know what he wants. He'd get his hair cut at the butcher if I let him.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, isn't this interesting? You're afraid.

speaker: EMILY
words: That Rory will enjoy the club and have a good time without you.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well why don't you just let Rory decide?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Because Rory is the sweetest kid in the whole world and she won't tell you that she doesn't want to go becasue she's too afraid of hurting your feelings.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh I'm sure you can give her some coaching to help her get over that.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm not trying to hurt your feelings, Mom. Believe it or not, this is not about you.

speaker: EMILY
words: Of course it's about me. If Rory goes and has a good time without you, then I win.

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, Bob Barker. Listen, Rory knocks herself out all week at Chilton. Weekends are the only time she has to unwind and have fun.

speaker: EMILY
words: So let me get this straight. There's no way that Rory can possibly enjoy a weekend day with her grandfather.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're just going to twist it all around, aren't you?

speaker: EMILY
words: And you know your daughter so well that you don't even have to ask her opinion on this. She'd be miserable and you know it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I am so setting myself up here, but yes, she would be miserable.

speaker: EMILY
words: That sounds a little controlling to me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah I walked right into that.

speaker: EMILY
words: Interesting, isn't it, you being the one who's controlling?

speaker: EMILY
words: According to you I was the only one in the family with that particular gift.

speaker: EMILY
words: I guess you and I are more alike that you thought, aren't we?
(Later, Lorelai and Rory are leaving for home.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: (sighs) Oh, man, did you get blindsided? I'm so sorry.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I tried to stop it, I swear.

speaker: RORY
words: I know. Maybe it won't be that bad.

speaker: RORY
words: Maybe you could come with me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, is there a "you're crazy" team? 'Cause I think they'd make you captain.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Rory, I love you. I would take a bullet for you. But I'd rather stick something sharp in my ear than go to the club with you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'd rather slide down a banister of razor blades and land in a pool of alcohol than go to the club with you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Don't stop me, I'm on a roll. I'd rather eat my own hand than go to the club with you. Ooh, I'd rather get my face surgically altered to look like that lunatic rich lady with the lion head than go to the club with you.

speaker: RORY
words: Would you like me to drive so you can continue your diatribe?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Would ya? Thanks. I'd rather cut off my head and use it as a punch bowl than go to the club with you.
(Cut to the inn. Lorelai escorts the brides, Jackie and Jessica, and their mother around the grounds.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: You'll walk down here over the bridge with the swans floating by and the music playing --

speaker: JACKIE
words: What are they doing with those purple flowers?

speaker: JACKIE
words: I didn't want purple flowers. I wanted pink.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So I thought violet would be a nice compromise.

speaker: JACKIE
words: But we paid for pink flowers.

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: You did not pay for anything. I told her to decorate with violet flowers and while it's very nice of her to try to take the heat for me it's certainly not necessary. If you don't like it, buy your own flowers. (silence) Yes, I thought so. Now go away. My Advil is wearing off.

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: They're spoiled. And they won't move away.

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: Now, disaster list. What if it rains?

speaker: LOREAI
words: Well, then we'll secure everything and put extra hair spray in everybody's hair.

speaker: LORELAI
words: We'll use umbrellas and fans that won't cause any damage because of the things that have been secured and the hair that has been sprayed.

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: So I have nothing to worry about.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Listen, I have everything under control. Why don't you go up to your room and have a fabulous bubble bath and I'll send up some wine and a masseuse who bears a remarkable resemblance to Antonio Banderas.

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: This is my favorite place in the whole world.
(Inside the inn Michel is handling gift baskets.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: (to an employee) Could you send Maury up to room twelve in about twenty minutes? Thanks. (to Michel) So, any problems?

speaker: MICHEL
words: With the wedding or my life?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Do you stage these events to torture me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, let's start again. Any problems?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Guests are checked in, baskets are given out, and 200,000 tons of Jordan almonds have been delivered.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hmm. She's golfing all day with my father and I'm half expecting this big "save me" call to come in -- you don't care at all do you?

speaker: MICHEL
words: To me you are the teacher in the Charlie Brown cartoon.

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, forget it. So, have the grooms arrived? Their plane was supposed to get in a 7 so I'm surprised they're not here by now.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Well maybe they made a run for it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh, somebody got stood up at the prom.
(Male twins have just walked in the front door.)
(The brides rush into the grooms' arms.)

speaker: MICHEL
words: You kept this from me on purpose.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's like a really snooty Doublemint commercial.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Just let me know when the midgets and clowns arrive.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, no, no, no. You have to get them all settled in.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Well I'm not talking to them nicely.

speaker: RICHARD
words: You're supposed to tee off at your designated time.

speaker: EMILY
words: You pay good money to that place. You'll tee off when you tee off. Is that what you're wearing?

speaker: RICHARD
words: What's wrong with what I'm wearing?

speaker: RICHARD
words: She's a sixteen year old who would rather be at the mall.

speaker: EMILY
words: Make sure you show her all around the club, especially the rose garden.

speaker: EMILY
words: And make sure you take her to lunch and have her get dessert.

speaker: RICHARD
words: No one said anything about lunch.

speaker: EMILY
words: I hope Lorelai's clubs are still in good shape.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Emily you are not listening to me. I will teach her to play golf, as promised by you, but lunch is out of the question.

speaker: EMILY
words: So you'll eat together. Do you ahve sunscreen?

speaker: RICHARD
words: 30. We must remember to buy her a watch.

speaker: EMILY
words: Richard, so help me God, you will be sweet to this girl and make this a memorable day for her. This is the first time we've gotten to show our granddaughter off at the club and it means a great deal to my happiness -- and yours -- that this day go well. Are we clear?

speaker: EMILY
words: This is a perfect day for golfing, isn't it Richard?

speaker: RORY
words: Am I dressed OK? I didn't have any of those short pant things.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well, actually there is something missing. Oh, wait a minute...
(She puts a hat on Rory's head.)

speaker: EMILY Here you go. Now you look just like Tiger Woods.
words: EMILY Here you go. Now you look just like Tiger Woods.

speaker: EMILY OK, off you go, you two. Have a wonderful time.
words: EMILY OK, off you go, you two. Have a wonderful time.
(Cut to Richard and Rory walking along the golf course.)

speaker: RORY
words: Is it hard to become a member here?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Everyone has to go through a thorough screening process.

speaker: RICHARD
words: We're much more thorough than that.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Yes. Did you know the merger of Forscape and D.S.S.

speaker: RICHARD
words: International finance will never be the same and all because of a lost golfing bet.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well that's high finance. Well, here we are. Now, what do you know about golf?

speaker: RORY
words: That it's a good walk spoiled?

speaker: RICHARD
words: (sighs) Well, your driver is the most powerful club in your bag, and as such, it can be your most valuable asset or your greatest liability. To wield it properly requires a precise combination of confidence and humility.

speaker: RICHARD
words: There you are. That's a pretty good natural grip. Now, line the toe of your left foot up with the ball. That's right. Now, drop this shoulder a little bit. Now, keeping your left arm firm, draw the club back, swing it cleanly through the ball.
(Rory takes a swing and hits the grass.)

speaker: RICHARD
words: (wearily) There are no rights and wrongs to the learning process. Try that again.
(Cut to the kitchen at the inn.)

speaker: SOOKIE
words: These are blueberries. I think ordered strawberries.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Yeah, no, I did. I wrote it down. I got a copy. (reading) Yeah, mushrooms, melon, endive, peaches, kiwi.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh I should make some kiwi ice cream. That would be good sometime.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Listen. I know you ordered strawberries but they weren't any good so instead of selling you sub-standard strawberries, I brought blueberries.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I've got to make strawberry shortcake for 200 people. I think I'm gonna need strawberries.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Hey, the world was flat until someone took a boat trip.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Coffee, coffee, coffee. Ooh, Sookie, can I take some of this cake home to Rory? She's going to need a special treat tonight. She's spending the entire day with my father golfing at the club.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Golfing was masterminded by my mother, of course. One minute we're having an excrutiating family dinner and the next she's manipulating my kid into spending her Sunday with my father at the country club. Oh, I can't talk about it anymore. It's making me too upset. Tell me something happy.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I can't make the strawberry shortcake.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow. You suck at this game.

speaker: MICHEL
words: The battle for soup versus salad is waging in the other room. Come quick and settle it, please, as I'm running out of French curse words that they won't understand.
(Lorelai and Michel go into the lobby where the twin brides are in each others' faces arguing between soup and salad.)

speaker: JACKIE
words: Salad...why are you making such a scene, Jessica? Jessica you are making a --
(Mrs. Shales walks over to Lorelai and Michel.)

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: It's been 45 minutes of soup or salad. Soup or salad -- I can't do it anymore. Get me a cab. I'm going to go far away now and never come back.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How about if the guests get a choice of soup or salad?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know. I think the one on the right is Matt.

speaker: MICHEL
words: No, the one on the left is Matt. The one on the right is Mark.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Yes, well, I'm very good at observing people, you know, learning the tics and traits, sound of their voices. It's a gift.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: That one has a Post-It on its back.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Oh, well, then that's Mark. The one on the right is Matt.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You will go and take that off of him.

speaker: MICHE
words: I will not. We can't all just call everyone 'sweetie' and get away with it.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Now, go with me, here. Let's say Mark walks into a hotel room and he sees his wife naked, but it's not his wife, it's his naked sister-in-law, and he has sex with her. Would that be cheating?

speaker: MICHEL
words: If you ask me this union belongs on a public access station. It's against the laws of nature and just this short of completely obscene.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, you won't be giving the wedding toast.
(Lorelai is walking Mrs. Shales to the door.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well I wasn't wildly fond of her during labor.

speaker: MRS. SHALES
words: That was the high point for me.
(Cut to Rory and Richard walking on the golf course.)

speaker: RORY
words: I can't believe I hit the ball!

speaker: RICHARD
words: Yes, but the splash was quite impressive.

speaker: RORY
words: This place is so beautiful. I could see just coming here to think or read. But that probably defeats the purpose of the holes with the flag thing.

speaker: RICHARD
words: There is something rather serene about walking around here.

speaker: RORY
words: Do you come here every week?

speaker: RICHARD
words: No. When I can. I'm often working on the weekends.
(Men in a golf cart pass by.)

speaker: RORY
words: Can I ask you a question?

speaker: RICHARD
words: I'm the executive vice-president of the Gehrman-Driscoll Insurance Corporation.

speaker: RORY
words: And as executive vice-president, what do you do?

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, it's a very big company -- one of the largest in the United States as a matter of fact -- I have a myriad of duties which would bore you greatly to hear about.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well, it rates a parking spot.

speaker: RORY
words: Do you get to travel a lot?

speaker: RICHARD
words: I suspect you have a yen for travelling.

speaker: RORY
words: I'm up to my ears in yens.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Any particular place you'd like to go?

speaker: RORY
words: Hundreds of places. Paris, Rome, London, Prague, Istanbul, Fez -- Have you ever been to Fez?

speaker: RICHARD
words: I can't say that I have.

speaker: RORY
words: I want to go to Fez.

speaker: RICHARD
words: I think travelling for a young girl is a very important thing. Your mother never got a chance to travel much.

speaker: RORY
words: I know. She talks about that all the time.

speaker: RORY
words: We've got a deal. When I graduate from high school we're going to go backpacking through Europe together. You know, do the whole hostel thing. I just hope it really happens.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Well we'll just have to make sure that it does.
(A golf cart pulls up beside them.)

speaker: GLORIA
words: Aren't you sweet? Is Emily here?

speaker: RICHARD
words: No, I'm taking my granddaughter for a round of golf.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Now, we'll meet back here in forty minutes?

speaker: RICHARD
words: And then, if you like, we can get some lunch.

speaker: MAN #1
words: And I'm telling him I've been coming here for twenty years my young friend, and for twenty years that cart, number 43, has been my golf cart.

speaker: MAN #3
words: Did he give you the cart?

speaker: MAN #1
words: Damn right he gave me the cart.

speaker: MAN #2
words: You should have never had to ask because he should have known that.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Heard about your golf cart. Too bad.

speaker: MAN #1
words: Yeah, well, I'm still angry about it.

speaker: MAN #3
words: Richard, who was that young lady I saw you on the golf course with?

speaker: MAN #3
words: You're lucky. My granddaughter looks like she just fell off a potato truck.

speaker: MAN #2
words: My granddaughter would never be caught here. Might get in the way of the time spent at the tattoo parlor or getting something pierced or doing whatever she does while she runs wild through the streets like a rabid dog.

speaker: MAN #1
words: Cut her off! That would get her attention!

speaker: MAN #3
words: I can help you with the litigation.

speaker: RICHARD
words: Said she wanted to learn golf. I think she's taken to it quite well.

speaker: MAN #1
words: Yeah, well, just as long as isn't taken with a certain golf cart.

speaker: MAN #2
words: I'm writing a letter to the board.

speaker: MAN #1
words: I wish you would. If they would take --
(The men go back to their golf cart discussion. Cut to the women's steam room. Rory listens to the gossip.)

speaker: WOMAN #1
words: And you know she took the house.

speaker: WOMAN #2
words: She deserved it -- putting up with that tramp all those years.

speaker: WOMAN #1
words: Last year, Christmas, he bough them both the same bracelet.

speaker: WOMAN #2
words: She should have just shot him like his first wife did.

speaker: WOMAN #1
words: Oh I love Janie. Is she out yet?

speaker: WOMAN #1
words: Oh, I just came for the steam. We must get together and play sometime soon.
(Cut to the inn. The staff is still decorating for the wedding.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, I need more tulle here. I need the feeling of a major tutu, OK? Oh, uh, hey, Gary, Gary! The ribbons go on the chairs, OK, not on the trees. Oh, great!
(Lorelai hears swans and goes down to meet the truck.)

speaker: SWAN GUY
words: Where do you want the swans?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well do you know where the pond is?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know that little road you came up?

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK. Do you know how to say 'big help' in Chinese?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Michel! (to Swan Guy) This is twenty swans?

speaker: MAX

Miss Gilmore [ hands Rory her paper with a ‘D’] Take these home, learn from your mistakes. Look at the large red circles around various parts of your paper as friendly reminders that to err is human. And that here at Chilton we try to beat that humanity right outta ya! Ok, next up. The test - the dreaded test. Shakespeare! The man we’ve been droning on about for the last three weeks, finally comes back to haunt us on Friday. This is a big one my friends - multiple choice with an essay section that will count for 20% of your grade for this semester. And don’t be fooled by my kind face and charming personality. This test will be hard, and there will be no makeups. [bell rings] Refer to the study materials that I gave you at the beginning of the month and those extensive notes I know you’ve been taking.

words: Right. Well I know that this is a terrible intrusion but - are you cooking?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: No wait. I found out your address from my network of culinary friends -

speaker: LUCENT
words: Look, this is really inappropriate. I gave you a good review, I suggest you go home.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I don’t care about the review. I just - I want you to try this disk, with this wine [handing them to him still with her back turned] I’ll wait.
CUT TO LORELAI AND RORY DRIVING HOME

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, I just think that we should talk about it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re just feeling like an impromptu nature walk?

speaker: RORY
words: I wanna see if it’s ok.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sweetie you’re never gonna find the deer.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It’s dangerous in the car with all the kamikaze deer running around [getting out of car]

speaker: LORELAI
words: Alright, wait up! So what does the deer look like? Huh? Does it have any distinguishing marks - besides the word ‘Jeep’ imprinted on it’s forehead.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I had a nice chat with Headmaster Charleston today. He said you went ballistic in class.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You wouldn’t have been so tired if you hadn’t been killing yourself all week.

speaker: RORY
words: I was studying, I didn’t have a choice.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well maybe you shouldn’t be studying that hard.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re 16. You should get some sleep and eat a real meal and come up for air once in a while.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, of course not. They love you. This is coming from me.

speaker: RORY
words: Are you saying I should quit?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m saying, if you wanted to go back to your other school with Lane, that would be fine with me.

speaker: RORY
words: You don’t think I can do it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know that’s not true. I think you can do anything. But you don’t lose it in class. That’s not part of the Rory personality description and if you’re losing it in class because you’re tired or stressed or working to hard, I’m worried about that. I have to be.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ok, fine. It’s just I can’t remember, you know, a time when we weren’t talking about you going to Harvard. It was just a given, that what we were working for. Everything went in that direction.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And I’m forgetting where all that started.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’m talking about - did it start with me? Or did it start with you? Was it my dream that you go to Harvard.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Because I never got to do the big fancy college thing? Maybe all this time I’m thinking it’s all for Rory, when really it wasn’t.

speaker: RORY
words: I’m not doing this because of you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Because if you are, you don’t have to.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I’ll still love you. Even if you can’t support me in my old age in the fabulous manner to which I plan on growing accustomed.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. I just want you to be happy.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I want you to be ‘dancing through the woods crazy’ happy. And if Chilton and Harvard is not gonna do that for you, then forget about them.

speaker: RORY
words: I was just behind. I never caught up with all the reading. That’s why I got a ‘D’. I can catch up. I will catch up and when I do, everything will be fine.

speaker: RORY
words: You know Harvard is my dream. I want it more than anything, I swear

speaker: RORY
words: I appreciate all that you’re saying. I do. But I’m not ready to give up on Chilton yet.

speaker: RORY
words: I do however reserve the right to change my mind.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That’s your prerogative as long as you remain a woman.

speaker: RORY
words: For yelling at the Headmaster the way you did.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, I didn’t yell at him.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You’re welcome. How much longer are we gonna look for this crazy deer?

speaker: RORY
words: Just a little further. I just hope he didn’t hurt himself.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I just hope he has insurance.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Go get that plaid skirt off and grab your books, we’re going to Luke’s.

speaker: RORY
words: Don’t you have to get back to work?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ah, they can last a little while longer without me. Plus Michel gets so cute when he feels like he’s been overworked. His ears puff out, his nostrils flare, big fun. Go.

speaker: LORELAI
words: [voice on answering machine] It’s us, we’re not here. We have a life, get over it.
[Lorelai closes books in the living room as she listens to the message, then sits on the couch]

speaker: MAX
words: Hi this is a message for Rory. It’s Max Medina calling. I just wanted to say that I talked to Headmaster Charleston or ‘il duce’ as he’s more affectionately know at the Gilmore household, and he’s agreed to let you do some extra credit work to help make up for the missed test today. Now I’m not sure what the extra credit work is yet, but it probably will be time consuming and extremely painful. It will however get you back up to where you rightfully belong Rory, don’t lose heart. Make this work. And if you’re mother is listening, Lorelai it was a pleasure encountering you. I hope it happens again. Anyways, see you in class. Bye.
(Lorelai, Rory, and Emily Gilmore are sitting around the dinner table.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: So where'd you say Dad was?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Germany. Is Dad's firm insuring Nazis now?

speaker: EMILY
words: Your father doesn't know any Nazis.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know, Mom. I was just --

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, I'm afraid I have some bad news. Claudia died.

speaker: EMILY
words: Claudia. Your cousin Claudia. (Lorelai stares.) Claudia!

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm hearing the name, Mom. I have no idea who that is.

speaker: EMILY
words: Claudia's your cousin, for all intents and purposes.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, now we're getting to it.

speaker: EMILY
words: She was your father's grandmother's sister's girl. So to you, that would make her --

speaker: EMILY
words: Regardless the funeral's on Thursday. I thought we'd all go together.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ooh, whoa. Two problems. Impossible to get away from the inn Thursday. Two, I've never met this woman.

speaker: EMILY
words: We went to her house in Groton to see the first moon landing. She'd just gotten a new Philco.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I have no memory of this whatsoever.

speaker: EMILY
words: Rory, correct me if I'm wrong, but men have walked on the moon regardless of whether your mother remembers it or not.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know men have walked on the moon. I just don't know Claudia.

speaker: EMILY
words: I don't think Claudia's planning to die a second time.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, I couldn't go if I wanted to.

speaker: EMILY
words: No, a Nazi that we knew. I'd forgotten. We stayed with him once in Munich. Nice old man. Interesting stories.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom you socialized with a Nazi? That's despicable! That's heinous!

speaker: EMILY
words: No, dear, that was a joke.
(Cut to Lorelai's kitchen. It is morning and Lorelai is seated at the table drinking coffee. Rory walks into the kitchen and closes her bedroom door on loud music.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey. I have an idea for a new reality show. How about everyone just looks out their freakin' kitchen window for a change?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Let's just say the world has a formidable opponent.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know. Shouldn't you be knitting?

speaker: RORY
words: Mom! The Chilton bake sale is today!

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know. I got it covered.

speaker: RORY
words: They expect the things to be homemade.

speaker: RORY
words: By someone other than Dolly Madison.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I said I have it covered.

speaker: RORY
words: All of the parents pitch in so this is really really important. You know that, right?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I didn't know that. In that case I don't have it covered. I have it covered! Get your stuff and hit the stereo -- we're late.
(Rory opens her door and we see Lane dancing in the room.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: (to Lane) Where does your mother think you are?

speaker: LANE
words: Oh, on a park bench contemplating the reunification of the two Koreas.
(Cut to exterior of the house. Lane, Lorelai, and Rory walk down the front steps and start to cross the yard. Lane waves as she runs off.)
(Babette and Morey walk by. Morey is pulling a wagon with Cinnamon -- their cat --inside. The wagon has a covering like a baby carriage.)

speaker: BABETTE
words: Yeah, Morey made it. Cinnamon's not walking good these days but she still likes her passeggiatas. That's Italian for 'a nice walk.'

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh God, he makes it sound so sexy.

speaker: LORELAI
words: (points to the covered area) What's that?

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh it's Cinnamon's private area. Sometimes she likes to be alone. She's just like Morey in that sense. (to Morey) Hey, say passaggiata again.

speaker: MOREY
words: I can't do it on command, Babs.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, he's blushin'. God, I love a man that blushes!
(BABETTE and MOREY walk away, pulling the wagon.)

speaker: RORY
words: Okay, our town is just weird.

speaker: RORY
words: I'll see you later at school.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Ha! I got the vein in the forehead. Whoo!

(Cut to a busy street. People are walking by on the sidewalk. Rory is sitting on a bench. A bus pulls around the corner and stops in front of her. Dean is walking down the street and sees Rory get on the bus. He gets on and sits behind her. Rory opens her book and beings to read. She doesn't notice him.)

speaker: DEAN
words: I saw you standing in line so I thought I'd say hello. (pause) Hello?

speaker: DEAN
words: Oh, hey, uh, thanks for helping me get the job at the store. I mean it's not a career or anything but it's got me solvent.

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, uh, are you always this serious?

speaker: DEAN
words: So, uh, how long does it take you to get to school?

speaker: RORY
words: Um...forty minutes if the bus driver's focused but longer if he's trying to win something on the radio. Hey, this bus is going to Hartford!

speaker: RORY
words: But you go to school here. You have to get off the bus! (calls to driver) Hey, he has to get off the bus!

speaker: DEAN
words: Buses make stops. Good-bye Lorelai Gilmore.
(Cut to the inn where Michel is on the phone.)

speaker: MICHEL
words: Independence Inn, Michel speaking. Yes, you are confirmed. Mm-hmm. Goodbye.
(Michel hangs up the phone as a group of businessmen approach the counter.)

speaker: MAN
words: Bonjour Monsieur. Vous êtes francais? Vous parlez francais?

speaker: MICHEL
words: Sir, I'm just a simple country boy from Texas. I do not understand this francais business you're babbling about.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He knows you're not from Texas.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Michel, I told you there was going to be a French group here for a couple of days and it is your job to keep them happy.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Lorelai, I don't know how many French people you've met over the years, but most of them are insufferable.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Mm-hm. That is why I left France.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Huh. I thought it had something to do with the torches and the villagers. Michel, talk to them.

speaker: MICHEL
words: Never. (pause) You are giving me that look aren't you? Your patented, "Do it or something unspeakable shall befall you" look. (sighs) Fine. I shall be French but I shall not be happy.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Then you will be yourself. Good choice.
(Michel goes back to the French group.)

speaker: MICHEL
words: Bonjour messieurs. Je m'appelle Miche. Ce soir pour vous aider.

speaker: MAN
words: (laughs) Vous avez faîtt un blague. Très drole! Très drole Michel!
(Cut to the bake sale at Chilton.)

speaker: SOOKIE
words: OK-- we've got our French fantasies, American treats, and our Italian taste sensations. Well, what do you think?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It is good, isn't it? Well, final touch.
(Sookie prepares to light a swan-shaped dessert on fire.)

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Whoa, honey, this is a more delicate procedure than you might think, OK?

speaker: (SOOKIE lights the tablecloth on fire. Lorelai fills a cup with lemondae from a nearby table and extinguishes the flames. The women at the lemonade table give her dirty looks.
words: (SOOKIE lights the tablecloth on fire. Lorelai fills a cup with lemondae from a nearby table and extinguishes the flames. The women at the lemonade table give her dirty looks.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Um -- hi. Oh, well, gee...what is that, a dollar? Let me find you a dollar. You know what? I'll take two -- I'll drink one. (drinks) Mmm...tasty and flame-retardant.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Good to see you, Mr. Medina.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mr. Medina. Meet Sookie, the cheft at the inn. Sookie, Mr. Medina.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I know, you've said it like a zillion times. (to Mr. Medina) Hello.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Hello. Lorelai, could I borrow you for a second?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, yeah, sure. (to Sookie) Oh! Hey I'll be right back.
(Lorelai and Mr. Medina walk away from the table.)

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: You know, Lorelai, I would love for the ice to thaw.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Well you repeated my full name four times. That's ice.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, that's not ice, it's wintry.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I was doing my job when I didn't let Rory take that test. I didn't like it but I had to do it.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I really do think Rory's a great kid and I'm going to do my damnedest to make sure she gets through Chilton in one piece.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: And I'd like us to be friends.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah. Really, truly, I swear. There's no more ice. We're walking in a pool of tepid water.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I'm going to propose something here. I'm not sure how you're going to take it.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I'd like to see you sometime. Away from the ivy, away from the gargoyles, away from here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Are you asking me out on a date.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mm. Well, uh, I don't want to go out on a limb here, but I'm guessing if the headmaster won't let a kid be thirty seconds late for a test he'd probably frown on a teacher dating a mom.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I do my job well, I'm dedicated to my students, and there's nothing in the Chilton book of ethics that prohibits it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah but I'm guessing it's sort of an unwritten rule.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And Rory would probably freak at the thought.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And the other parents would have a field day with this kind of thing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I can't. It's wrong. It's weird.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm kidding. I don't know. You're Rory's teacher.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Could you quit? Right, that's crazy.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: OK, OK. Um...how about coffee? You like coffee?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Can we drink some together? A sort of pre-date. Very casual, no strings, no obligations. We'll just see if it's even worth going down the road of including food in the deal. (whispers) Just coffee. (normal voice) Decaf? There's nothing safer than decaf.

speaker: LORELAI
words: 12. I could not stop a person from entering said establishment around that time, nor would I avoid them if I knew them if they did.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: You know the wordsmith thing -- that's something we have in common.
(Cut to Lane and Rory walking down the street.)

speaker: RORY
words: Philadelphia? If you could live in any city in the world you'd pick Philadelphia?

speaker: LANE
words: The guy who directed 'The Sixth Sense.'

speaker: RORY
words: But what would you do there?

speaker: LANE
words: Hang out with M. Night Shymalan.

speaker: RORY
words: OK, cross 'guidance counselor' off your list of potential career choices.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Lie still, baby doll, we're almost home.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Cinnamon's dyspeptic. So's Morey. Too many clams.

speaker: BABETTE
words: This doesn't reflect well on Al's establishment.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Yeah, well we had a coupon.
(Rory and Lane resume walking down the street. Rory spots Dean in the grocery store where he is working.)

speaker: RORY
words: Oh wow! The store! Hey, listen, I have to pick up some stuff, so --

speaker: LANE
words: What do you have to pick up?

speaker: RORY
words: Just some...stuff. So I'll talk to you later tonight.

speaker: LANE
words: Because otherwise I'd have to go home.

speaker: RORY
words: Yeah, actually I don't have to go in.

speaker: LANE
words: OK. Then I guess I will go home.
(Lane leaves. Rory walks into the store and watches Dean. He looks over and waves when he sees her. Rory ducks into an aisle and walks to the back of the store where Miss Patty is.)

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Rory! Hello! Try a plum They're better than sex.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Fresh fruit always has such a sensuality about it. Are you too young for this?

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Well what are you here for honey?

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, I see what you're here for. Well that wouldn't fit in a basket. No no no no no!

speaker: RORY
words: Patty! It's not like that. He's just a person.

speaker: RORY
words: I really don't even know him.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, right. You don't know him?

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: I promise I won't tell a single soul that you don't know that young man.
(Rory walks away from Miss Patty. A store employee confronts Miss Patty, who has been sampling the produce.)

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: Excuse me, ma'am, what are you doing?

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Please, honey, don't call me ma'am. It makes me feel older than 25. Here, have a pea pod.

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: I assume that you're going to pay for the food you've consumed on the premises.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, so brusque. And you are?

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: I'm the new assistant manager here.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Well listen here, my fine friend, who if you had a better hairstyle i might consider dating, I do this all the time.

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: Not from now on, I'm sorry.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Oh, now, wait a minute here. I've been sampling food at this establishment for years.

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: The next time you put something in that mouth that doesn't belong there, I'm going to remove it and then call the police.
(He takes the pea pod out of her hand and walks away. By now Rory is at the check-out counter. Dean walks over to the end of the counter.)

speaker: CASHIER
words: Is this all you want, honey? A head of lettuce and a mouse trap?

speaker: DEAN
words: That's a couple of must-need items there.

speaker: DEAN
words: I could loan you the rest.

speaker: RORY
words: Uh, no, I'll just take the lettuce.

speaker: DEAN
words: Perfect. You could use half of it for a salad then use the other half to clobber the mouse with.
(Cut to Lorelai entering the coffee shop in Hartford. She sits at the counter near Mr. Medina.)

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I wanted some cream but that prompted a very elaborate foam conversation. And the look of disapproval I got when I said I didn't want foam, just cream, rivaled the one I got from my dad when I told him I wanted to be a teacher.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow, so it's been a tough outing for you, huh?
(The waitress goes to get Lorelai's coffee.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Should we cut the cute and just get right to it?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Because I think we both want to.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well I want to be in the Bangles but that doesn't mean I quit my job and get a guitar and ruin my life to be a Bangle, does it?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Well it's got to be part of the point if there's no band anymore.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Because we're clearly attracted to each other.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm attracted to pie. It doesn't mean I feel the need to date pie.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Wow! Round one and already tapped.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Look I know that you are concerned about the appearance of us dating.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Well I can tell you that I am the soul of discretion when it comes to delicate relationships.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Dated a lot of Chilton moms, huh?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: No, I meant any relationships -- work, family.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh so you have things to hide in all aspects of your life -- very interesting.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: (to waitress) Do you have any hemlock back there? Arsenic, something quick?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Me too. You just telling me what I want to hear?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Doesn't mean it doesn't coincide with how I really feel.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah but if you're telling me what you think I want to hear then I'm not really getting to know you.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: And if I know what you want to hear that shows a level of understanding on my part that far exceeds your understanding of me. (Lorelai doesn't say anything). Who's the one laggin?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Wow, round one and already tapped!

speaker: LORELAI
words: (seriously) Rory is my life. She's my pal, my everything. And I would never, ever do anything that would hurt her.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I understand. (A man sits down on the stool between them.) But Rory is not a baby anymore.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Don't say that! She's eight! She's eight and her favorite hobby is making necklaces out of gum wrappers.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: You could try stunting her growth, keeping her in a box, blowing cigarette smoke on her.
(The man gives Mr. Medina a strange look.)

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: You are so taking this out of context.
(The man moves to another seat. Mr. Medina moves into the seat next to Lorelai that the man vacated.)

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: OK, when my uncle was a young man, there was this girl who lived across the street from him and he was completely in love with her -- but he never talked to her. But he knew in his gut that this was the girl he wanted to spend the rest of his life with.

speaker: LORELAI
words: This is gonna be sad isn't it?

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: So anyhow my uncle watches this girl, waiting for the right moment to approach her. Next thing he knows, he gets drafted.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: No. Now he thinks 'this is perfect. I'll come back, I'll have a career, I'll have served my country, I'll be worthy of her love.' When he gets back -- she's gone. Moved away. No one knew where and he never saw that girl again. Now my uncle, he didn't say much to me, but the one thing he did say was that if there's something in your gut that you know you feel is right you gotta go after it, no matter what. What do you say?
(Lorelai sighs. She takes out a business card and writes on it.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Maybe dinner wouldn't be so bad.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Dinner? You mean we could sit together? Even drive together?
(Lorelai tosses the card at Mr. Medina.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, that story about your uncle -- is that true?
(Cut to Luke's cafe. Luke serves Lorelai and Sookie.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thank you. (to Sookie) Life is a funny funny thing, huh?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Yeah I love that Jim Carrey.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Jim Carrey. He's just -- he's just -- funny.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He is funny but I didn't mean funny, funny. I'm being philosophical.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh. Very serious face. Jean-Paul Sartre.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I can't talk to you with that face.

speaker: LUKE
words: How do you guys get any work done?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: So why is life such a funy thing?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah there's goody stuff about it but there's baddy stuff too. He's a teacher at Chilton. Max -- you met him at the bake sale.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah. Right. He's so sexy and smart and funny and he likes coffee.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: God, he sounds perfect for you. Did you get onions?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: (calls to Luke in the kitchen) Hey Luke! You forgot the onions.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm just so mixed up though. You know this is a real crossroads kind of situation.It's like 'to perm or not to perm.' I'm really confused.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: For Heaven's sake. (Sookie goes around the counter to get the onions. She starts adding things -- onions and spices -- to the other customers' plates.)

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Go ahead, I'm still listening. You were about to perm your hair.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I just want to do the right thing.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I'm not sure I see what the problem is.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh there are many problems. First -- I do not like to involve Rory in my personal life. I don't want her to have to deal with that. You know, I might bring some guy home and he might not be THE guy but then she gets all attached to him and then all of a sudden I decide that I don't like the way he eats or he hums incessantly or --

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Or the way he smacks his lips or how his hair isn't really his.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah. And then I break up with him and then Rory is the one who gets hurt.

speaker: LORELAI
words: This guy is her teacher. I mean, there's no way to keep him out of her life. She sees him every day.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: (to a bearded customer) Are you the open-faced turkey?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: OK, I added a little fresh lemon and a little cayanne pepper. You're gonna plotz! (to Lorelai) You od know that Rory's not a baby anymore.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know, that's what he said. Maybe I'm being too serious, right? Maybe I should loosen the rules a bit. Plus, be great to get...you know.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Hey. I was just looking for your paprika.

speaker: LUKE
words: What have I said about the counter?

speaker: LUKE
words: How the counter is a sacred space. MY sacred space. You don't do yoga on the Dalai Lama's mat and you don't come behind my counter, period.

speaker: Luke takes Sookie by the shoulders and walks her back to the other side of the counter.)
words: Luke takes Sookie by the shoulders and walks her back to the other side of the counter.)

speaker: LUKE
words: (to Lorelai) You bring her again and I want her on a leash. I mean it.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: He does make a damn find burger though.

speaker: LORELAI
words: He does at that. Alright I'm just going to keep it simple. I'll tell Rory. If there's even an ounce of weirdenss about it I'll cancel.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, not oops. The timing hasn't been right. This is a very delicate, fragile situation. It's like one of your souffles. If you don't do it right it's a disaster.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: And you have to order it 45 minutes in advance.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right, I wasn't but speaking directly about your souffle. I was speaking metaphorically.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh so you don't like my souffles?

(Cut to Lorelai and Rory pulling into their driveway. They cross the yard and go to Babette's. There is a Stars Hollow Animal Hospital van in the driveway. Inside Babette's house, Cinnamon's body is lying on the floor covered by a sheet. The vet is just standing up as Lorelai and Rory enter the house.)

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, Lorelai. Come in, come in. She's gone. Cinnamon's gone.
(Rory goes over to Morey and sits next to him.)

speaker: RORY
words: Is there anything I can do for you, Morey?

speaker: MOREY
words: This is life, Rory, it breaks your heart.

speaker: BABETTE
words: She looked like she was sleeping. I thought she was asleep so I nudged her and she didn't wake. I gave her a push and she rolled off the couch and since I waxed the floor she went shootin' across the room and then she knocked over the lamp and she still didn't move. I knew it was over. Oh, God, my baby.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, Morey, don't do this to yourself. He thinks it was the clams.

speaker: MOREY
words: She saw me eating them and she gave me that 'hey, man, what's up?' look and --

speaker: VET
words: It wasn't the clams. Morey, in human years this cat was 260 years old.

speaker: VET
words: Listen, why don't you let me take her out to the van and then I'll get out of your way.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, no, stay. All of you, please stay. Cinnamon would want you here.

speaker: RORY
words: We'll stay as long as you want.
(Time lapse. Babette's house is now full of mourners, with more arriving all the time.)

speaker: LANE
words: They said that they rolled her body into a lamp.
(The bearded customer from the cafe walks by as Michel comes through the door.)

speaker: MICHEL
words: Hello? Hello? Where is Lorelai? I'm dropping something off. Yoo-hoo, 'Hee-Haw' man, where is Lorelai Gilmore?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hey, hey, hey. Thank you. I could not get back to the inn.

speaker: MICHEL
words: What, you are having a party and I was not invited?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sweetie, it's not a party, it's a wake.

speaker: MICHEL
words: They lick their privates, these cats.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Not the comforting chitchat we're looking for here. Goodbye. I'll talk to you later. Thank you.
(Lorelai pushes Michel out the door just as Miss Patty is pushing her way in.)

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Babette, Morey, I came as soon as I heard. Oh, darling, what do you need?
(Miss Patty grabs Babette and hugs her and presses Babette's head into her large chest.)
(Outside, Sookie and Luke arrive at the same time, both carrying food.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, bless you both! Everyone's starved, come in.
(Sookie and Luke both try to go through the door at the same time and collide. They back up and Sookie rushes in before Luke.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, how should we do this?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Well we need a flow for the room so there's no bottlenecks. People coming in, they're gonna want a beverage. Put 'em on the first table then the smaller hors d'oeuvres next to that, leaving one hand free to greet the people. Then, back there, set up plates and cutlery. First the salads, then the meat dishes, then desserts on the piano bench. How does that sound?

speaker: Luke dumps his bags of food on a table in the middle of the room.)
words: Luke dumps his bags of food on a table in the middle of the room.)
(Time lapse. Rory answers a knock at the door. It's Dean with his arms full of drinks. He has to duck to get in under the low door frame.)

speaker: DEAN
words: Oh, hi, wow. I wasn't expecting you.

speaker: RORY
words: Or me you. I mean, you, me. I mean, come in.
(Dean takes the drinks into the other room. Lorelai walks by.)

speaker: RORY
words: Well, he goes to my old school, so I see him there sometimes but I go to Chilton now.

speaker: RORY; I have to get back.
words: RORY; I have to get back.

speaker: DEAN
words: Oh, sure. I'll see you later.
(Dean leaves. While watching him out the window, Rory sees Mr. Medina at her door.)

speaker: RORY
words: Well, am I in trouble? Did the school call or something?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, no you're great. I -- um -- let me just come back in just one second.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Let me tell you in a minute.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Max is here to pick me up.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'm gonna go talk to him real quick and I'm gonna be right back.
(Rory looks upset. Lorelai runs outside and over to her own porch where Mr. Medina is still knocking.)

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: I was knocking but no one answered.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know. I was at the neighbors' house.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know it's totally last minute.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I just completely forgot about our date.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No you're memorable. I've been memorabling all week. It's just -- We had a little emergency.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, Rory's fine. It's the neighbors' cat.

speaker: LORELAI
words: This was a very fat, very beloved cat.

speaker: MR. MEDINA
words: Lorelai. I like you but I don't want to force something on you that you don't want so -- (walks away)

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, no, no. Wait. No, Max, you're not forcing anything on me. I am telling the truth about the cat.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Please don't read that much into this. Call me and we'll reschedule. I promise that's what I want.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Cross my heart and hope no other neighborhood pets die on that day.
(Mr. Medina gets into his car and drives away.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Stupid cat! You couldn't have held on one more day?

speaker: LUKE
words: You gonna make fun of my mother too?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Sorry. You know, my real-fruit puffs would compliment that dish quite well.

speaker: LUKE
words: It's fine on its own, thank you.

speaker: LUKE
words: OK, toss some on the plate.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Can I make a pretty design, maybe make some layers?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Right. Tossing them on. Got it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You guys, have you seen Rory anywhere?

speaker: LUKE
words: Yeah, I think she headed that way. (points)
(The grocery store employee from earlier approaches Miss Patty.)

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Well if it isn't Kirk the jerk.

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: I want to apologize for what happened at the store yesterday.

speaker: EMPLOYEE
words: I wasn't aware that you were THE Miss Patty. The owner tells me that you're one of our best customers and you can put anything into that mouth that you want to. Those were his words. I could have paraphrased them.

speaker: MISS PATTY
words: Stop sweating. And close your pores, Kirky, I always forgive.
(Lorelai fins Babette in the kitchen cleaning out a cabinet full of pill bottles.)

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, hello, sugar. Can I get you something?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, I'm fine. I'm looking for Rory.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, I think she might be in the bathroom.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Thanks. (starts to leave then stops) Can I help you with something?

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, no. I thought I'd just get some of this stuff packed away.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's like a scene from a kitty version of 'Valley of the Dolls.'

speaker: BABETTE
words: Yeah. You never realize how old they actually are 'til you look in the medicine cabinet.

speaker: BABETTE
words: These were for her heartworms, for her thyroid, her kidneys, for the rash she got from taking these, and these were for the tic she developed from the stuff for the rash. And these -- oh jeez, these are mine. Damn, I'm gonna miss that old broad.

speaker: BABETTE
words: You know, I don't know what I'm gonna do with myself now. You live to take care of your kids.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know, sweetie, but you gave her everything that you had.

speaker: BABETTE
words: I know. She was so tiny when I got her. She could sleep in my shoe.

speaker: LORELAI
words: The other day I came across a hat that I made for Rory. It was like a doll hat.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, they grow up so fast.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And then they take your clothes.

speaker: BABETTE
words: I guess eventually you have to move on. Figure out what your life is going to be when you're not busy taking care of somebody else. Jeez, look at this place. Not a clean glass in sight!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Let me help you with that.
(They start to wash the glasses but the sink is too low for Lorelai. Babette gets a stool for her.)

speaker: BABETTE
words: Here, sugar, use this. Morey sits on it when he helps me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: How does Morey get around in here?

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, just fine. He had a couple of concussions his first year here but he never complains. He's just the best thing. I don't know what I'd do without him. (voice breaks)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, Babette. What do you mean 'without him'?

speaker: BABETTE
words: I saw on Oprah a few weeks ago. She had on couples who lost a child. Most of the marriages went belly-up for the pain of it all. Even though they loved each other.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Babette, that is not gonna happen to you.

speaker: BABETTE
words: I never thought a man would ever even want me.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, please, with that ass? Gimme a break.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I mean want me for more than my ass. Me -- for me, the whole package. Annoying neuroses and all.

speaker: BABETTE
words: You'll find him. It might even be that stud who drove out of here in a Mustang.

speaker: BABETTE
words: How is he in the sack?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I haven't even gone out with him yet.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Will you tell me when how he is when you do?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I'll call you during the cigarette.
(They hug. Lorelai hits her head on a low-hanging overhead lamp. They hear [iano music from the other room.)

(Cut to the living room. Everyone is seated or standing quietly listening to Morey playing the piano. Miss Patty is beating on a drum. Babette goes over to sit with Morey. Lorelai finds Sookie in the crowd.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh I can't find Rory anywhere.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Max showed up for the date that I forgot about and she saw him.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: OK, calm down. It's not that big of a deal.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Her teacher showed up on her porch to take out her mother.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: She'll understand. You're crazy. She knows that.
(Rory is outside in Babette's yard, surrounded by gnomes. Dean walks up to her.)

speaker: DEAN
words: Yeah, uh, look. I just wanted to say that I'm sorry.

speaker: DEAN
words: Well I've been kind of bugging you lately. Uh, I thought -- I don't know -- I thought that maybe you liked me. But it's obvious that you're not interested so I just wanted to say that I get it and I'm not gonna bother you anymore.
(Dean starts to leave. Rory gets up and follows him.)
(Rory leaves and Dean smiles. As Rory reaches the door Lorelai comes out.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh! Finally. I've been looking everywhere for you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Listen, I have some explaining to do. OK. So sit down in that tiny little chair and I'm gonna do it right now. (Rory sits.) That man on the porch was your teacher.

speaker: RORY
words: Mom, I'm a little behind in school but not so far behind that I don't know who the teacher is. So?

speaker: LORELAI
words: So -- um -- he and I were going to sort of hang out together.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, on a -- something that could appear like a date to the untrained eye.

speaker: RORY
words: How long have you been dating him?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I haven't. This was gonna be the first time.

speaker: RORY
words: And when were you planning on telling me about this -- your wedding?

speaker: LORELAI
words: No -- by the rehearsal dinner at least.

speaker: RORY
words: He teaches me things every day in a very small classroom with a lot of other kids who probably won't be high-fiving me when they find this out.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I knw, sweetie, and I told him this was one of the things I was concerned about.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And he thought we could be discreet.

speaker: RORY
words: Information that I should have had.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Information that would have come out eventually. Like the Iran-Contra scandal.

speaker: RORY
words: I just can't believe that you didn't tell me about this. Why wouldn't you tell me?

speaker: LORELAI
words: 'Cause I thought you were going to take it bad. Thank God I was wrong. (pause) OK, OK. Listen, I'm sorry. I won't date him. I promise.

speaker: RORY
words: I'm not saying that you can't date him. It's just -- this is weird. I mean -- there's a million guys in this world and you end up with Mr. Medina.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You think I don't get the weirdness factor? Believe me, the last thing I intended to do was date your teacher.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I really like him, Rory. I can't help it. And it's been a really long time since I've felt like this. You can't always control who you're attracted to, you know. I think the whole Angelina Jolie/Billy Bob Thronton thing really proves that. And I know you don't understand this now but you wil someday. You'll meet some great guy and he'll make your head all foggy and you won't know what to do with yourself. (sighs) Oh, sweetie, I won't keep anything from you again. OK? I promise. From now on every aspect of my life is an open book to you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Really, I'm not even going to get dressed until I tell you what I'm thinking of wearing.

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, tomorrow I'm thinking the purple tiger top, the black leather skirt, the panda bear underwear.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But of course I'm totally open to suggestions.
(Lorelai and Rory are leaving Babette's. Babette and Morey walk them out.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Let us know if we can do anything.

speaker: BABETTE
words: Oh, you've done too much already.

speaker: MOREY
words: Let's stay outside a while, baby. Look for the Big Dipper.
(Morey puts his arm around Babette's shoulders and they watch the sky.)
(The phone rings as Rory and Lorelai walk in their front door.)

speaker: EMILY
words: I've been trying to get you all afternoon.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well there's no messages on the machine, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: I don't leave messages. If I wanted to talk to a machine I'd talk to my VCR. Where were you?
(Rory motions Lorelai not to say it.)

speaker: EMILY
words: Hold on. I'm looking up anyuresm in our medical dictionary to see if I just had one.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I just wanted to be honest with you, Mom. Silly me.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, a cat. It was a cat's funeral.

words: You skipped your own cousin's funeral for a cat's funeral?

words: Not my cousin, mom. My father's grandmother's sister's girl who I've never --

words: You said you couldn't be away from the inn.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well I couldn't at the time bt I worked it out.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's late. I have a big day tomorrow, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, what? You're going to a racoon's wedding?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Aaagh! She's working for a sedative manufacturer. Keeping that demand sky-high.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well I don't know what to tell and what to hide.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So we never did quite settle the whole dating-your-teacher issue. I won't go out with him if you don't want me to.

speaker: RORY
words: You can go out with whoever you want.

speaker: RORY
words: Well I'm certainly not going to go out with him 'cause that would be really weird.

speaker: LORELAI
words: But I mean it. I won't see him if you don't want me to.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You know, if there's anything that makes you feel uncomfortable, big or small, then he's out of there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Because you know it's not like I'm desperate. I mean, there are plenty of other guys out there.

speaker: LORELAI
words: And it's not like I have to ask your permission. I mean, this is a courtesy.
(Rory goes into her room and closes the door. On the other side of the door, Lorelai raises her voice to be heard.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, so I'm going to be up for a while, if you want to get back to me on this.
(Lorelai starts to leave. Rory opens the door and sticks her head out.)

speaker: RORY
words: Hey, do you think you could keep him out really late on Thursday night because I have this oral exam on Friday that I'd really love him to sleep through.

speaker: EMILY
words: Tomorrow our lawyer, Joseph Stanford, is coming by.

speaker: EMILY
words: That's terrible. Sissy was a good friend of yours.

words: Mom, Sissy talked to her stuffed animals and they answered her.

words: Let's just start a new topic.

words: She said a new topic, Mom.

words: Everything's a joke. Everyone's a punch line.

words: Sorry for that. A little trouble with our China office. Well. What did I miss?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I was being impossible and then I turned into a Jewish comedian.

speaker: RORY
words: Uh, Joseph Stanford is coming tomorrow.

words: Yes. So, Rory, your grandfather and I thought it might be nice after dinner for you to go around the house and pick out what you'd like us to leave you in our wills.

words: Take a look at that desk in my office. It's a really fine Georgian piece.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Why don't I ever bring a tape recorder to these dinners?

speaker: RORY
words: Oh, well, anything you want to leave me is fine.

speaker: EMILY
words: Nonsense. You should have what you like. So look around and when you see something you like stick a post-it on it.

speaker: LORELAI
words: OK, you two have officially hit a new level of weird that even I marvel at.

speaker: EMILY
words: You can pick out things too, you know.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, well now it's way less creepy.

speaker: EMILY
words: Did you hear that Richard? Apparently we're creepy.
(The maid comes in with a tray.)

speaker: EMILY
words: Well if you knew what it was why did you ask?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, I love pudding. I worship it. I have a bowl up on the mantel at home with the Virgin Mary, a glass of wine, and a dollar bill next to it.

speaker: RORY
words: I've never had pudding from a crystal bowl before.

speaker: EMILY
words: Put a post-it on it when you're done.
(Lorelai and Rory are putting post-its on on things in the living room.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: So what do we think of this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I don't know. The Emily and Richard Gilmore Psycho Museum?

speaker: RORY
words: This is the strangest evening I've ever spent here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Great, just getting ready for the big day.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, um, it's getting late, Mom. Unless you've got some funeral plots for us to decorate we should really be going.

speaker: EMILY
words: Any special requests for dinner next week?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, I want to talk to you for a minute, and Rory, why don't you go say goodbye to Grandpa...

speaker: LORELAI
words: Yeah, but not there, OK? We got a post-it on that. We'd like to keep it nice.

speaker: EMILY
words: It must be very exhausting to be you.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, Rory's birthday is next Friday.

speaker: LORELAI
words: So we were thinking that maybe we could push our dinner next week to Saturday.

speaker: EMILY
words: What are you going to do on Friday?

speaker: EMILY
words: Well perfect. You'll come here and we'll have a little party.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I was just hoping we could do it another night.

speaker: EMILY
words: Well why come on another night when her birthday falls on the exact night that you do come here.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Saturday's a pretty good night, Mom.

speaker: EMILY
words: I'm sorry. Friday nights are my nights. That's what we agreed on when you borrowed money for her school. The rules haven't changed.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, I didn't intend for this loan to become a constant source of blackmail, OK? Now this is my kid's birthday and she will have her party at home on Friday and that's it? End of story.
(Cut to Rory and Lorelai sitting in the car.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: So, how would you like two parties this year?

speaker: RORY
words: You couldn't get her to cave.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, but she did agree to make the string quartet to learn "Like A Virgin."

speaker: LORELAI
words: Sweetie, I promise, Saturday night we'll do it up right at home. A Stars Hollow extravaganza.

speaker: RORY
words: So, is this party Grandma's having going to be a big deal?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Not really. The government will close that day. Flags will fly at half-mast. Barbra Streisand will give her final concert...again.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Now, the Pope has previous plans, but he's trying to get out of them. However, Elvis and Jim Morrison are coming and they're bringing chips.
(Cut to the inn. Lorelai is in the kitchen with Sookie.)

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Mini orange biscuits with honey-mustard ham and cheddar cheese.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Oh, did you bring me the picture?

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Too bad you couldn't get your mom to relinquish Friday night.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, she has her Vulcan death grip on that one.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Emily Gilmore -- you could set your watch by her. Oh, you know what she did do last night?

speaker: LORELAI
words: I mean, I'm sure it was some expensive form of pudding, but nonetheless, it was pudding!

speaker: LORELAI
words: Right. That would mean that she actually made a mental note that we liked pudding, which would mean that she actually listened to something other than the judgmental conga line going on in her head, and got over the fact that, to her, pudding is hospital food, and only acceptable when you've just had vital organ ripped out of your body.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Wow, that's some journey she had to take there.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Open your mouth and close your eyes.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Right, sorry. (goes to Sookie) Open your mouth and close your eyes.

speaker: JACKSON
words: Now get ready for something truly amazing.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: I don't know. It's like, um...

speaker: SOOKIE
words: It's like a berry, but way more exotic.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Jackson, have you been having reactions to your fertilizer fumes again?

speaker: JACKSON
words: For some time now I've been toying with cross-pollination. Finally I've got it. I figured out a way to cross a raspberry with a kumquat.

speaker: SOOKIE
words: Kumquat! That's what I taste! Are you serious? How did you do this?

speaker: LORELAI
words: You didn't build one of those machines like in "The Fly" did you? We're not going to find you wandering the streets wearing a raspberry head crying, "eat me!"
(Michel comes in and Jackson walks over to him.)

speaker: JACKSON You! You can make fun of me all you want to today, 'cause tday I am a god. Today, Mother Nature has bowed down to me.
words: JACKSON You! You can make fun of me all you want to today, 'cause tday I am a god. Today, Mother Nature has bowed down to me.

speaker: MICHEL
words: No need to fill me in. I'm quite happy being ignorant of whatever it is that is making him raise his arms over his head.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, hey, Rory's birthday party is Saturday night so start thinking up reasons why you can't come.

speaker: MICHEL
words: I'm going to be out of town.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, you used that last year.

speaker: MICHEL
words: I'll work on it and get back to you
(Cut to Lorelai's house. Rory is on the phone.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: 'And Justin is just so dreamy. He can't marry Britney, I'll just cry and cry and cry.'

speaker: RORY
words: (into the phone) OK, thanks. (hangs up phone) Pizza's on its way.

speaker: LORELAI
words: You're such a good provider. Hi.

speaker: RORY
words: I'm going to start my homework. Call me when the pizza guy gets here.
(Rory goes to her room. The phone rings.)

speaker: EMILY
words: Lorelai, what is your work schedule?

speaker: EMILY
words: I think that goes without saying.

speaker: EMILY
words: I want to get Rory a birthday present.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well I'm sure whatever you get her, she'll love.

speaker: EMILY
words: Yes, but I want to get her something special, something she wants, something...that you would get her.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, OK, fine. You can get her the bong then.

speaker: EMILY
words: This isn't funny. I hardly to see the girl and we only get to talk at dinner once a week and then it's all about school and Jane.

speaker: EMILY
words: I thought you might let me into her secret club just this one time and help me buy her something for her birthday.

speaker: EMILY
words: According to you I'm always serious.
(Cut to Chilton. Rory is opening her locker.)

speaker: TRISTIN
words: I just wanted to say 'happy birthday.'
(Rory takes the paper. It's an invitation to her birthday party, from Emily and Richard.)

speaker: TRISTIN
words: I don't know. Everyone in our class, I think.

speaker: TRISTIN
words: I'll see you Friday, birthday girl.

speaker: GIRL #2
words: My parents are making me go.
(Cut to a department store. Emily points to a hat.)

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, yeah. As soon as we have her crowned Queen of England we'll give it to her.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Hatwear does that to me. Oh, Mom, look. This is good.

speaker: LORELAI
words: It's a purse shaped like a guitar. This is great.

speaker: EMILY
words: What will Rory do with that?

speaker: LORELAI
words: She'll put stuff in it. Carry it around.

speaker: LORELAI
words: That she's an ax murder, of course.

speaker: EMILY A double string of pearls with a cashmere sweater set.
words: EMILY A double string of pearls with a cashmere sweater set.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Mom, she's a young girl. Think of something young.

speaker: LORELAI
words: To put on her desk at the law firm?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Well not with a $200 pen, she doesn't. Oh, hey, look. These day planners are adorable. You could get her one of those funky erasers with a mermaid on it. She'll love that.

speaker: EMILY
words: Please be serious, we're shopping for Rory.

speaker: LORELAI
words: No, Mom, I'm shopping for Rory. You're shopping for your imaginary granddaughter, Barbara Hutton.

speaker: EMILY
words: I want to get her something nice.

speaker: LORELAI
words: I know you do, but you're not listening to me.

speaker: EMILY
words: You wanted me to get her a Filofax and a mermaid eraser.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh, yes, and there was a T-shirt with a Farrah Fawcett face.

speaker: LORELAI
words: A hero to many who aspire to the perfect feather fluff.

speaker: EMILY
words: Oh I don't know how to do this. Let's just go.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Oh, no, no. Come on, Mom. You do know how to do this. Think pudding.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Come on. You asked for my help. You're reaching out. A little -- not a lot -- don't get freaked. But, Mom -- pudding.

speaker: EMILY
words: Why do you keep saying pudding?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Listen, just look around and pick up something she might like.

speaker: EMILY
words: Doesn't look like something you could buy at a car wash?

speaker: LORELAI
words: Six dollars more than a car wash.

speaker: EMILY
words: Twelve dollars is not a present.

speaker: LORELAI
words: Twelve dollars is a perfect present, Mom. She'll love that.
